items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The Thames Barrier is expected to close for the predicted high water at Richmond at 05:00 on Thursday 29th April 2021.

We are not currently planning to close the Barrier for the following high tide at 17:30 on Thursday 29th April 2021 and this Flood Alert message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday with the forecast river levels.

Astronomical tide levels peak on the next tide.

The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 38 cubic metres per second and is steady.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.
   
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.

Although levels have declined during the last few weeks, we expect levels to remain high and low lying land and roads therefore remain at risk of flooding.
  
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 
 
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 5 May or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Porlock Weir with sea spray expected as a result of a high tide and strong winds this evening. The forecast high water is at 20:45 on 28/04/2021 with a level of 6.67 mAOD and a Force 4 north-easterly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, and mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible at this time, and conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates where appropriate and checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: A flood alert has been issued. The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides between 20:15 and 21:45, tomorrow, Thursday 29th April. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly around Southfield Farm and Spurn Road, Kilnsea. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Thursday 29th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected over the high tides on Tuesday 27th, Wednesday 28th and Thursday 29th April due to high spring tides. Water levels will be raised between the period of 05:00 tomorrow, 27th April and 19:45 on Thursday, 29th April. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect  coastal and tidal areas between Hartland Point and Lynmouth, including the Taw Torridge Estuary. 
 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the highest forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is at 06:30 on Wednesday at 5.09m AOD.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

Areas most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Thursday 29th April, or as the situation changes.

Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides between 19:15 and 21:45 on Thursday 29th April. Areas most at risk are seafront areas, low lying land and roads in Hornsea. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: Waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides. Flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible tonight, Wednesday 28th April, between 22:00 and 02:00 tomorrow morning. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. It is forecast that the lunchtime high tide tomorrow, Thursday 29th April, will also reach the Flood Alert threshold. This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday 29th April, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast today and over the next few days. Forecast high water is at 21:15 on 28/04/21 with a level of 7.67 metres AOD and a Force 4 North Easterly wind. Second forecast high water is at 09:30 on 29/04/21 with a level of 7.69 metres AOD and a Force 2 South Easterly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Properties are unlikely to flood at this point but tides are rising and we will be updating this flood alert for the remainder of this week. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Our incident response staff will be monitoring the situation and on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Thursday 29/04/2021.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
The high tide is expected to be higher than usual as a result of high tides. Consequently flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible from 12:15pm today 28/04/21.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry between 12:15pm and 13:00pm , with a peak of 6.26m, Eastford Road between 12:30pm  and 13:45pm, with a peak of 6.41m, and Arpley Bridge between 12:45pm and 13:30pm, with a peak of 6.46m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. Based on current forecast, the next high tide is not expected to reach flood alert threshold, however, the midday tide tomorrow 29/04/21 is expected to reach the flood alert threshold. We will issue further updates to this message as necessary.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Brockweir as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 8pm and 10pm this evening, 28/04/21. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  A series of high tides is due over the next 24 hours. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
The tide peaked Wednesday morning, 28/04/21 at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.79m & Newport at 7.41m.
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 8m at 9:15pm on 28/04, Newport 7.3 to 7.5m at 9:15pm on 28/04.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads along the estuary which may be flooded at high tide.  
This message will be updated  by 11pm on 28/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 3am tomorrow morning, Thursday 29th April. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.87 mAODN at 2am tomorrow, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind Force 5, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 19:30 and 20:30 Wednesday, 28/04/21. Flooding to the promenade and seafront is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront. The local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
  
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 4.64 mAODN. The forecast surge height is 0.00 m. The forecast tide level is 4.64 mAOD. The forecast wind direction is north east. The forecast wind strength is Force 6

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
Waves are forecast to overtop sea defences at Brockweir as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be at their highest between 8pm and 10pm today, 28/04/21. Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  A series of high tides is due over the next 24 hours. High tides may impact properties and roads in and around Brockweir on the Wye Estuary. The tide peaked this morning, 28/04/21 at Avonmouth Portbury at 7.79m & Newport at 7.41m.
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7 to 7.9m at 9:15pm on 28/04/21, Newport 7.3 to 7.5m at 9:15pm on 28/04/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths along the estuary, which may be flooded at high tide.  
This message will be updated  by 11pm on 28/04/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 00:45am and 2:45am tomorrow morning, Thursday 29th April.  Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect high tide levels at Felixstowe Ferry waterfront and riverside areas at Woodbridge and Waldringfield. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.63 mAODN at 1:45am tomorrow, which is 0.36m above tide tables, wind Force 5, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).    Take care on coastal roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and Mar Dyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is 03:45 on Thursday 29th April 2021.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 9am tomorrow morning, 29th April 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This has been issued due to the high tide forecast for Thursday morning, 29/04/2021. Highest tide level is expected to be at 01:30 on Thursday. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time from 23:30 to 03:30. Flooding to properties is not expected, however we are monitoring the situation. Areas of concern include Faversham and Conyer.
Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and may be issuing further messages during this time. For those who need it, the forecast total water height at Sheerness for the 01:30 Thursday morning tide is 3.51mAOD.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 29/04/2021, or as the situation changes.
